text:
There's a pretty well established theory that the two girls were likely abducted by two men they'd met up with the day before. They'd have to have passed too many residences and populated areas to not have been able to reach help. Their bodies were, after all, found 12 hours away from where they first tried to contact help.

The trails to where their remains were found are clearly marked, were easily navigable at that time of year, and would have taken the girl's through populated areas.

A guard who would have been in the area on the theorized day they were abducted had heard screaming, but hadn't been able to identify the source.

The pictures on the camera that are all black? May have been them attempting to use the flash to get the attention of a group of campers who would have also been nearby.

It's likely that Kris died on April 3rd, and Lisanne tried to log into her phone multiple times. Kris's bones were unnaturally white, containing high amounts of phosphorus- not a chemical naturally present in the soil where their remains were discovered.

Both girls' bones were unmarred- which is not normal. Even if their deaths had been natural, animals chewing and clawing at them would have left some kind of mark.

It's thought that the girls' bodies were soaked in some kind of chemical containing high amounts of phosphorus, effectively dissolving the outer layer of the bones and smoothing over any marks that may have been left. That's consistent with the condition of her foot, which is severed at a spot that would not be likely to be natural, which also shows no markings.

It's evident to me that the girls were likely followed or arranged to meet up with some cute guys they'd met and, as a result, met their end.

text:
I think the dog ran off the trail (chasing an animal, or it decided to go home), Kris and Lisanne went after it, going far from the trail, and they became lost and disoriented in the jungle. If one of them were injured, it would slow them down, and infection, in that environment, would be certain, if the injury was severe. Dehydration, starvation, and exhaustion would slow and disorient them even further, as the days went on.

IMO the backpack was left when she became too weak to carry it, then days/weeks later some random hiker touched (possibly moved) it, leaving fingerprints, but didn't bother to take it. 

The photos were taken as a means to light up the jungle in the dark. The missing pic is before the first night shot, so maybe they took a pic in the day, before the situation became dire, and they didn't like the shot, so they deleted it. 

Such a sad case, and so horrible that the local police didn't send out a search party on the first day, when they might have been found alive.

text:
my dad is a roofer, a commercial roofer, meaning he does hotel and business's roofs. he mostly just stays in florida, but he does go out of state, sometimes out of country if its a high paying job. he did a job in Jamaica, a VERY nice and luxurious resort that was paying a TON of money for my dad and his workers (dads a regional manager) to fix a bunch of leaks and damages. so they went, and on the way from the airport, the shuttle to the rental car place was a rickety bus. someone literally tried to ROB them. like at a stop, someone flung open the door and said to empty their bags. the driver got up and BEAT THE GUY WITH A NIGHTSTICK. he fell onto the road and the driver just kept on driving. my dad had seen worse growing up so he was unfazed for the most part. when he got to the resort, it was surrounded by giant walls. the manager said to never ever go outside the walls unless it was absolutely necessary. he gave them free rooms to stay in while they worked. he said the entire property was gorgeous and dreamy, like something out of a movie. but he had hired some Jamaican people to work with his crew as well, they needed money and my dad needed extra hands. so he went outside of the property, away from the safety of the walls to their bank to deposit their money every friday. the first friday, he was leaving the bank and witnessed an actual murder. he was in his car, and a man was crossing the street and going into the bank, and 3 people came of nowhere and stabbed this man multiple times, took everything from his pockets, his watch his shoes, and left him dead in the street. my dad sped out of there so fast, and told the manager at the hotel what happened. he always made sure to have 3 other guys with him when he left the walls every friday. he was gone for a month, and my mom was nervous the whole time and called him every night after he told her what he saw.


moral of the story, if locals tell you not to go somewhere, DONT GO THERE. especially when youre unfamiliar with the area. those countries are beautiful but thats what google images are for. my heart aches for those girls, but its not all like the movies. these other countries are not like america.

text: You left out a huge component of this case, by failing to mention a particular local guide who the girls became acquainted with the day before they began their hike. This guide had offered to guide them THE DAY BEFORE, along the same trail they took the following day. He had offered to take them down the trail & to his isolated ranch in the area to spend the night & then take them back. The girls declined his offer THAT DAY, but supposedly agreed to have him guide them the next day, whereupon the girls simply took off by themselves. We know this is mostly true, because the guide showed up at the house where the girls were staying to pick them up, but the host family told him that the girls had already left on the hike themselves. For some strange reason, the guide then demanded to see the room that the girls were staying in. The hosts allowed him to inspect the room. Some locals claimed the guide was very friendly & professional, while others, including tourists who had hired him in the past, stated he was a womanizer & had groped or tried to touch many women inappropriately. One local resort refused to use this guide due to the same reason. Also, this guide would only take parties of women, or at least women being present within a party, he would NOT guide "men only". THIS FACT ALONE IS VERY DISTURBING. This same guide also helped in the search & even pointed authorities to the exact area where some of the girl's possessions & remains were found. Very strange. Many believe he set the girls up for some kind of sex crime deep in the wilderness, killed them, and then spent the following days trying to cover up or at least stage the area to make it seem like the girls were alone & had some kind of serious accident involving deadly injuries. But the Panamanian authorities REFUSE to allow outside investigators to see the details of the case. The local authorities are more worried about keeping a good image for tourism, so they too, are guilty of trying to cover this case up. Locals stated the official search & ensuing investigation was a big joke. THIS IS YET ANOTHER CASE PROVING WHY WOMEN SHOULD NEVER TRAVEL IN ANY COUNTRY WITHOUT TRUSTED MALE COMPANIONS. Even "going out at night" in your very own town without male companions is not wise at all. Women are soft targets, and the sad truth, is there are far too many male predators running around.

text:
Panamanian here. I used to hike through that trail with my family and friends, so I got chills recognizing a few parts of the path in the video. 


The trail is clearly marked, and it travels through many houses of indigenous people, going through open hills, even a a few rivers while you ascend the mountain before it truly gets into uncharted rain forest. Even though there is a considerate amount of people at the base of the mountain (people live there, go there, theres even a restaurant connected to one of its entrances), the only exception to solitude is the occasional small hut in the higher areas.


In terms of terrain, it can be rather dangerous without a guide because there is little visibility through the tropical jungle, very rocky with sudden cliffs, but as stated before, the path is clearly marked and no one should get lost on their own. There are no large predators in the area, the only possibility for a dangerous animal would be venomous snakes, frogs, or plants. In terms of water supplies, there are a few streams and the like available, and our dry season ends at around that time, so there are chances of rain (Id have to look at the weather reports of those days).  Dehydration would be enhanced by hot water vapor and humidity, reducing their energy supplies.  None of the possible causes of natural death explain the condition their bodies were found.


Our police force is not prepared for emergencies inside dense tropical forests ironically enough. Their counterpart, SENAFRONT, has the jungle training, but theyre stationed around the borders to stop drug related crime. The further you go from the main cities, the less equipment, resources, manpower and know how SENAPROC has due to centralization by the government. Just to paint a picture and add more context about organization here, the legal justice system usually waits for years to properly solve simple crimes in court. 


Also I will add that pretty much everyone has a phone in this country, with 6 million phones vs 4 million people, with a clear emphasis for smart phones. Boquete is a small tourist town in the highlands, where there are a lot of retired and/or tourist European and Americans, with a constant influx of visitors. Really anyone could have the knowledge to access those phones and tamper with the info at a basic level. 

Also Jesus, they actually mentioned the girl killed in Bocas. Im kind of surprised with the connection made in the video, as right now there are rumors of an ongoing investigation of a serial killer through the FBI, that someone seasonally travels to Panama to target other tourists, specifically young white girls, before heading home as a type of vacation feature. There are previous cases of the like, ie the Wild Bill case.


(Also all the footage of Panama here is from Panama City, which is on the other side of the country, faraway from where these incidents took place.)

text:
I think They were simply unprepared. Panama, Costarica, Nicaragua, these are one of the most extreme jungles in the world. I used to read a book of ex special forces - Naval, about extreme training in Belize, which is not far from Panama's climate, and those were skilled commando unit, which needed a Local Guidance, group of Para Medics and drill instructors. Not to mention about equipment. 

Look how dressed They were. Shorts and camisoles? We are talking about enviroment, where You have to look out what root You're lean your hand on, cause some of them in specific time of year are giving off poisonous fluids, with these shorts its so freakin easy to cut yourself, and it's not far that some creatures smell your blood and bite the hell out of You.

Besides check out what gear They've taken on the trip. Two pairs of bras and a bottle of water. Freaking bottle of water. Is that a new type of survival? No map? No compass? Not to mention about, dunno... first aid kit maybe? Rescue flares?

Next thing - girl which has been hanged on her own shirt... Jesus Christ these things are happening while You're UNPREPARED. It's not some sort of magic or serial killer living in the jungle. It's stupidity at it's best. 

So dear teenagers - world ain't sunshine and rainbows. If You go on a trip do the research. Do your homework and be prepared.

text:
Questions:
(1) Assume they died from thirst, starvation, disease or a combination of these. Where were large parts of their skeletons - where were the large bones and the skulls? Why only a handful of scattered bones remain? It's impossible for whole skeletons to disappear after just a few months unless there's some skull-munching monster in that jungle!!  
(2) How were the phones and camera still working, the backpack and its contents not soggy and muddy having supposedly been out for months in the jungle? 
(3) One of them was a meticulous writer in her diaries. Why did she not at least record a short message on camera, perhaps a last word to her family and loved ones?? 
(4) A local tour guide had a shack nearby the trail. After the deaths, that shack was demolished - why wasn't this investigated???!

text:
interesting theory, definitely. although, most of the things you mentioned could be explained otherwise. the decomposition, for example, is faster in rainforests (because of the temperature and humidity, that makes it easier for all those tiny organisms to grow and decompose a body). and if they died because of an injury (maybe even got mauled by a wild animal or something), that would explain the state the bones were in. and they probably didn't dehydrate, since in a rainforest is plenty of water. and usually teenage girls don't have anything on hand to filter that, so they could very well have suffered from the effects of the water, while maintaining at least their hydration. that could explain the pin too, if that wasn't after the first girl died. and honestly, the deleted photo could just be a reflex, maybe before they knew they were in actual danger. often people underestimate the situations they're in. 
and if there was a murder, first, how did the killer knew the pin to delete the picture? it would be easier just to destroy the phone. and who took the photos at night? the girls would be better of hiding instead of making themselves vulnerable with the flash and still, in that case a killer would probably still destroy the phone to be safe. did the killer do that? and if yes, why? if he wanted to get attention, like some do, he'd show off their corpses or something. 

after all, to me it's more likely that some kind of animal killed them (or ate their corpses, that would be pretty likely actually), or they died in an accident or because of dehydration (or the poisoning, if they drank dirty water). but of course nobody can be sure what actually happened.

text: 8:00 - Just thought I'd throw this out there but every smartphone has to have to ability to contact emergency services, even without the PIN or other security measures, and even if the service is disconnected. So the idea that someone was trying to access the phone to call is off putting. If the phone was an apple device, the phone would've been locked out and even so the memory is encrypted to access. The only way I see this, is that someone was trying to access the phone for information (maybe the missing photo) and if they managed to remove this, this had to of been an SD card with pictures defaulted to save there or it was an un-encrypted OS running on the phone (possibly android). In which case you should be able to access the phone and track down logs of what devices accessed what on the phone....Hopefully stored meta-data would help

text: The discovery of the backpack led to new searches along the Culebra.[21] Kremers' jeans shorts, zipped and neatly folded, were found on top of a rock on the opposite bank of the tributary from where Froon's backpack had been discovered, and a few kilometers away (Although later witnesses would claim the jeans were not neatly folded but found in the river itself[22]). Two months later, closer to where the backpack was discovered, a pelvis and a boot with a foot inside were found. Soon at least 33 widely scattered bones were discovered along the same river bank. DNA testing confirmed they belonged to Froon and Kremers. Froon's bones still had some skin attached to them, but Kremers's bones appeared to have been bleached.[12][20][17] A Panamanian forensic anthropologist later claimed that under magnification "there are no discernible scratches of any kind on the bones, neither of natural nor cultural origin—there are no marks on the bones at all.

text:
Ok, so there are quite a few oddities to this story.


1. Why would they neatly pack their belongings in the backpack (including their phones...their only way of contacting help) and abandon them in the forest? If that were me, I would keep my phone on me even if dead just in case there was a possibility of being tracked via GPS. 
2. They found bone fragments of the girls...not whole remains. A corpse doesn't just up and vanish like that. Also...if the girl left to find help...how did both of their bone fragments end up found together? (I'm assuming - doesn't clarify). My guess is that either foul play is at hand OR they died of exhaustion and wild animals took apart their bodies, scattering the remains. 
3. 77 failed attempts? That feels like desperation to me. A normal person would maybe try about 20-30 times and call it quits...but 77 times? That seems like utter hopelessness to me. Also, don't these phones (iphones do) have disable timers? So if you type an incorrect pin X number of times it disables for X amount of minutes? So after 77 incorrect tries wouldn't the disabled time be pretty hefty? No way I'd be waiting for that (as a murderer). 
4. How long were the bodies/bone fragments left out in the wilderness? Autopsies should be able to identify time of death. This would give SO much more insight into when such and such died, leading to a much clearer picture. 


My theory: the dog got spooked/intrigued by a wild animal or bird, then ran off. Girls tried running after it, but to no avail. Realize they are lost and now call the emergency line...to no avail. (Also, maybe this is when Kris got injured? Around April 6th, she perishes and Lisanne is sadly left alone. She takes Kris's phone, and tries to unlock it throughout the next 4 days, getting longer and longer lock times (she has a samsung and probably does not know how to get to the emergency call w/out pin option). After some amount of time, she dies from exhaustion. Now, this still doesn't explain the bag...not sure how those items ended up in there and away from the corpses. Something does not add up...and I don't know what it is.

text:
Wait, that second theory about the other girl being left with the phone, trying 77 times to unlock it in order to call the emergency line.. 
Usually phones don't need to be unlocked at all to call emergency services. Those are the only numbers you CAN call from a lock screen.

Edit; yes, I looked this up. I thought maybe because they were foreigners, they would need to unlock to call local emergency services. But that's not the case:
"112 is the Emergency Number available Globally for mobile networks. All phones allow this number to be dialled even if the screen is locked."

So the idea about the second girl trying to unlock the phone to call 112 is invalid. Whoever was trying to unlock it was trying to unlock it for something other than an emergency phone call.

text:
Still difficult to accept this. I know the trail. I hired a guide walking there. I remember the Lonely Planet said you can do part of the trail by yourself, but at some point it gets dangerous. Thats why I took a guide. And because I wanted to find the beautiful Quetzals bird. When I heard about the girls missing it triggered me extra because not only I know the trail, the girls are also from my hometown in The Netherlands. I was still in contact with the guide and asked him if he knew what could have happened? Because I knew he was the best I was thinking why not asking him. He replied saying the girl had come up to him as well to hire him. But they didn't show up. (Probably because they where lost by then?). I never heard that in any official story. Than I asked him (all by messages) if he could look for them, try to find them or find out what happened. This guide found the remains after that. I think by himself. I saw him on the news. I didn't contact him after about it. They where found. Thats the most important. He is still guiding and one of the best. He's an older man and loved girls, but I don't think he has anything to do with it. I don't understand why he wasn't contacted right away. 
It is a very sad story. I did some trails on other locations in Central American jungle. And I'm always afraid for peccaries. Peccaries are wild pigs that eat everything. There are stories about that. I heard them ones and was extremely afraid. I personally think that after the died there remains where taken by animals like peccaries. I think there is nobody else involved. Only thing is they probably went to far ahead of the appointment they had later. Maybe out of enthusiasm and curiosity, because they wanted to explore in advance of the appointment a little bit. And maybe they went in deeper and deeper. Higher and higher. It is a rainforest but high in the mountains. It is a special vegetation, with big leaves. Very wet, rivers, mud. Rocks. Beautiful but dangerous if you don't know around or how to survive. Maybe I've just been lucky sometimes as I was lost. I found my way back and encountered the most beautiful animals. In Africa I was surrounded by lions in Samburu national Parc one night. It was scary. By making mistakes and being lucky I was finally taking more precaution. I also stopt skiing off piste when I saw 3 guys killed by an avalanche. I left a remote island in Thailand and one week before theTsunami destroyed it. All this is just luck. Stupid luck. Only solace in this case is the girls died on an adventure. And not is a stupid retirement centre. But way to young. Those beautiful souls. May they RIP.  And may God watch over them.

text:
A very common thread in these mysterious murders or disappearances is a failure of investigators. Here for instance the police didn’t take action for four days. Often this is the cause of the mystery, it becomes a mystery because we have a lack of evidence to come to solid conclusions. The really sad thing is that is often makes the case unsolvable, as in this instance. Without more evidence all we can do is guess. They were murdered, they got injured and used the phone as a light, they were kidnapped, they fell and died to the elements, all plausible theories but we can’t prove any of them, all you can do is create a circumstantial case that you believe to be the most likely and hope new evidence is found that helps solve it.

I am a bit puzzled by the fact we can’t definitively prove the orientation of the cliff picture though. It seems like someone smarter than me could use the plant leaves to tell if we are looking at the bottom or top of the leaves and determine whether we are looking up or down a cliff. I would think at least one of those plants has some differentiation between the top and bottom of its leaf.

text: I do find this one quite interesting I will point out something I think you'll find of note here, files deleted from camera memory or even SD card memory is fully recoverable if deleted in the traditional way because unless a deep format is performed the data remains available until overwritten. If a deep format was performed there would be no files whatsoever. So for that file to truly be irrecoverably deleted someone would have to delete the file then using data recovery software or something of the like remove the traces of the file kept in the drive or SD card's buffer, as someone who has dabbled in data recovery and modification I can tell you right now that this is not a simple task and most certainly CANNOT have been done by the girls in question so this leads me to believe that there most certainly was foul play involved.

text:
The " them just being lost in the woods and dying from lack of food and water " sounds like complete bull to me. From all the evidence collected, it almost seems complete obvious that this was a murder. First, they are in the rainforest, there are ways to filter water from streams with lack of supplies. Is it difficult? Yes, but there are ways, and if they couldn't filter it, then they could have just drank the stream water. Yes, it would be disgusting, but it would be essential for survival, and i would think of surviving first than " is the water crystal clear?"
Best case scenario, the water had no side effects, worst case, they got a brain eating paritiste and died from that. ( i highly dont think that happened though )
But, they could have packed enough water to last a while but they were taken out, Or, A fellow hiker saw they were lost and supplied them with food and water, then said he knew the way out, so lead them and got them in a area in the woods where he thought no one would bother them. With other crimes, its always with someone leading them, saying they know the way out or that they can help them, when its the opposite. It seems like that could have happened here. As for the pictures, one of the girls could have been trying to get pictures of the suspect while either trying to get away or when they were in her/his " care ". And for the deleted one, the suspect must have sawn one of the girls take it, and he/she told her to delete it, since it could be evidence. The suspect could have even took the phone when it was unlocked and made the girls take the passcode off so they could go on and off the phone with ease, then put a new code on before dropping it or making it seem like they were trying to get in it. Or, they ( the suspect ) were taking photos and could have accidentally taken one with their identity being seen in it, even if it was minimal, anything works in a investigation, so they could have deleted it for that reason, since the person obviously knew that there would be a investigation. The rock picture could have been taken by the killer, and all the other strange pictures could by them too, and i believe they could have been a set of clues to the girls location on the phone, but that may not have been it. The rock picture does need some looking into though, since it has the flash used.
The shorts can have a easy or complicated explanation. One of the girls could have been bathing in the river/ stream or the killer, for whatever reason, took them off, neatly folded them and placed them on a rock as a clue, since these sickkos enjoy leaving clues for people since, in some cases, they enjoy attention and taunting police.

All and all, very strange case yet a very interesting one, and this comment made me realize I really need to stop watching dateline and crime watch daily  XDDD anywho, thats my theory on this

text:
I have a huge hunch that they were perhaps followed & kidnapped, and here's my theory of how things went down:


As they were hiking, they went off the beaten path & got lost.  With the dog returning home without them, I suspect that one (or both) of the girls fell and hurt themselves, and they released the dog hoping it would go home & therefore alert the host family. The girls likely stayed where they were until they realized how dark it was getting, and tried to get back by themselves while also searching for a signal to call the emergency line.  When darkness fell, they used the flash of the camera to find where they were going.  I'm assuming that photo 509 might have contained an image of the person who had been following them, or some other damning piece of evidence that led to that particular photo being deleted later by the person who took them.


Either way, I think that at some point, Kris became so injured or so exhausted that she likely passed away, and Lisanne took Kris' phone so that she could hopefully still contact authorities and save herself, explaining the multiple failed PIN attempts, although this could also be the moment that the person following the girls had gotten ahold of Kris & he was attempting to get into her phone to make sure there was no evidence of them on it.  Either way, I think that at this point, the person who had been following them grabbed Kris while Lisanne ran on alone.  Eventually, Lisanne came to the edge of the cliff in the last photo (assuming other commenters are correct about the photo), where she was cornered and taken.


And I think this psycho who found them left their backpack as a way to taunt the police.  The bleached pelvis could have been left by the killer, or could be something that the police made up to cover up their negligence in this story.  Hell, the police may have even found the bodies themselves, dead of exhaustion after being alone in the jungle for so long, but didn't want it to come to light that if they'd taken action a few days sooner, they could have located the girls alive, and subsequently be blamed for the girls' death.


As for how they survived so long without water, I'm not sure.  Maybe they had quite a few water bottles with them, and survived off that for so long by drinking extremely sparingly.  I mean, people's bodies can do some crazy shit when that survival instinct kicks in.


This story really is a heartbreaking one, with a lot of speculation and very little evidence.  It's an extremely dark situation, with multiple hard lessons for everyone to take from this.
1)  Always make sure someone other than the people with you know where you are going and when you expect to be back, especially if you're going hiking in unfamiliar territory.
2)  Never go off into the woods alone, especially not unprepared.  Plan for the worst, and take some time to brush up on basic survival tips, in case you do become lost.
3)  Always be aware of your surroundings.  You never know what could be hiding near you.

text: There was most certainly other people involved.  It's actually entirely possible that the people who say they only found the evidence were actually involved.  Given that only a foot in a shoe was found along with some stripped bone fragments, I'm thinking this was some kind of weird occult thing where their body parts were used in some kind of rituals (apparently this kind of thing happens in Mexico occasionally), or were possibly even consumed.  It's also possible this was some kind of medical cadaver thing, and that the bodies were essentially "donated to science," so to speak, and the remains that were found were planted in order to give the authorities some kind of plausible story that didn't involve foul play (basically the crap the police made up).  I find it strange that I never saw the wound at the top of the foot/ankle described as to whether it was something made by a knife, saw, axe, etc., or something that would indicate an animal tore it off/fed on it.  I do recall reading that the pelvic bone they recovered had been chemically treated, though, so foul play was definitely involved.  As to the missing image, that one seems obvious, even if they could somehow tell the image hadn't been deleted by the camera (how would you tell that), nothing says that the card wasn't pulled and the image deleted via a PC because it showed something incriminating, and for whatever reason they didn't simply delete everything completely.  I'm curious what, if anything, could possibly be recovered from the phone(s) since apparently whoever was trying to access them was unable to do so.  Phones also have tended to have cameras, after all.

text: The fact that that pelvis was sun bleached is extremely suspicious. I preserve bones as a hobby, and have observed the decomposition of animal corpses. A cow skeleton, for example, took a few years to decay to the point where only sun bleached bones remained in a shaded, arid, and hot environment. The heat and moisture would speed up decay drastically, but the fact that there has been evidence that victims of murder often have lime (?) put on their bones to speed up decay and hide evidence leads me to believe that this was a homicide. Of course, it seems that fats still remain on the bones, which is suspicious to me as well, since fats usually dissapear before bones are bleached. Not to mention that larger, less fragile bones such as the femur, vertebrae, or skulls (plus the other pelvis) were not found. Bones will be scattered by scavengers and the elements, but these bones do not just dissapear. It is possible that the girls were dismembered and had other parts dropped further into the forest,  or into the river mentioned previously (flesh in water will attract bacteria, which can strip a bone of excess tissue in about a month. It's what I use to clean bones). It just doesn't add up. I think that somebody killed those girls.

text:
If this was an "accident" or if they just got lost in the forest and died of starvation, then a lot of things don't add up:
1. The dog that accompanied them was able to find it's way home (unless it left them earlier in the hike). I imagine the dog should have been able to find them as well.
2. If someone got injured, then the other should have been able to seek help easily, especially since there are multiple paths and villages in the area (e.g, where the backpack was found). Especially if this monkey bridge is on a marked path.
3. The girls only tried calling 911, & didn't think to try and call their family/friends.
4. Regarding the night pictures, if they were only using the camera as a light source, then why didn't they use it during the other nights of their disappearance. How did they manage to get around the forest on the other days in the pitch black?
5. The backpack was left by a river bank, DRY (so it couldn't have drifted to shore). Not only that, but it was near a village, from where it's stated that people come to the area the backpack was found. Another reason why help shouldn't have been hard to find.
6. if one of the girls really did put the backpack by the river, then that would rule out death by dehydration.
7.  Only bone fragments were found, and not a full corpse/skeleton (ex. part of a pelvis hidden behind a tree, a foot). The foot was said to have been cleanly cut off. Unlikely it was eaten by a wild animal. Also, forensics found no scratches on the bones.
8. During the one phone attempt where they actually managed to contact 911 before cutting off, why didn't they try again afterwards?

text:
Out of all the cold cases I’ve seen, this one is the one that keeps me up at night. With most cold cases, you can at least sorta guess what happened to someone such as if someone last spoke to some weird person then yeah that weird person probably had something to do with it.

But this whole entire case… geez you just really don’t know what the hell happened. The fact that they only called the emergency number ONE TIME, the photos during the night, the path they took being practically impossible to get lost in etc… nothing just makes sense. And what sucks is that there’s no concrete evidence to support a theory, I mean it’s all just up for grabs by this point. Did they get lost and ultimately died with their bodies not found? Did they get murdered? Did they get kidnapped? Did they purposely kill themselves or get lost?

text: Couple notes: 112 is the emergency number virtually anywhere in the world if you're using a cell phone. You should only use convenience numbers like 911 if you're using a landline phone that does not follow this international convention. Second, and largely unanswered is how the girls managed to keep their phone running for so long off of battery. I doubt the iPhone/Galaxy phone could take hundreds of photos, make a few emergency calls, and be power cycled on and off for 8 days. Unless they had an external battery pack, which in early 2014 wasn't as prevalent as they were today, something doesn't add up. My guess is their phone remained powered on during the first day, then the perpetrator keep the phone powered on to lead investigators astray. Another thing: how come several calls to 112 lead to no answer? My understanding is that emergency numbers generally should work, even in more remote areas. It's one of the few things that actually you can somewhat count on. Unsure what the cell infrastructure was over there at that time, but it does seem bizarre that they'd try many times over a course of several days and not once did their call get connected. Taking a photo to activate the flash to see where you're going seems a bit strange, although I suppose in 2014 flashlight capability wasn't built in to all phones. However, it does seem a bit strange that again they would have the battery power to take all those photos, even activating flash and it all lasting several days. Another thing, why didn't they just wait till the following day for sunlight to descend from where they were and seek help? The most dangerous time to be moving is night time without any illumination.

text: That photo looking down the cliffside at night was light enhanced by forensics and showed what appeared to be a body shape sprawled at the bottom of that drop.  It was Kris, and there was another photo of Kris' head showing a large head wound.  The sticks were arranged to point towards her body and another marker was pointed towards the direction  Lisanne went in when she realised she had to leave her dead friend behind.  This was at the point of the monkey cable bridge also seen in the enhanced photos.  Lisanne also sustained a fractured foot at some point and also succumbed to the elements in her weakened state.  All the other conspiracy theories and leads fell apart on proper inspection and the forensics are consistent with this theory.  If the Panamanian authorities left that evening or first next morning, they would have found at least Lisanne still alive.  Shocking but all too familiar Incompetence.

text:
News like this always strikes hard in our country (The Netherlands).

We are a really small country and every little thing that happens is big news, and the whole country is affected by it, crazy right?

Our country has 12 province’s, each with their own little culture and dialect. Sometimes we can’t even all relate to each other. But when something like this happens, it’s like all we unite, and we remember we are one nation and one whole as people.

Same when the airplane MH-17 got shot down over Ukraine, carrying like 80% Dutch people, and for weeks / months, thousands of flowers were laid down by random people at the airport.

When some drunk lonatic drove straight at the queen when she was visiting a town (Apeldoorn) and hit loads of bystanders.

text: Man, just because a trail is regarded as “an easy trail” by the locals doesn’t necessarily mean it’s going to be easy for two foreigners with absolutely no prior knowledge of the terrain. We can argue it was foul play, but that camera at one point was used to light the way of the path.. which obviously means they were lost. If they were able to follow the “simple trail” they would’ve found civilization sooner. Being that this never happened, I’m leaning more on the side of them getting lost and dying due to dehydration and starvation. These two girls were not survival experts, they were vacationers. My theory is, they trekked too far off the path, and got lost. They began to move in one direction which probably drew them further Into the jungle. One of them along the way, got hurt or injured. Maybe even suffered a fatal injury, which led one of them to try and find help. This would explain the failed pin code attempts at one point. I believe eventually the other girl just died due to exposure of the elements. We know animals have been known to tamper with remains frequently. Why the girl’s backpack was left untouched is the only question I have. Another possibility is that, the effects of dehydration can cause delirium, which would explain taking off clothes and leaving her stuff behind. Very sad story, I hope the families are given closure one day.

text:
The biggest suspect in this case is Tour Guide F. This guy is connected in every way:
-He has 2 versions of what happened that are completely different which immediately makes him a suspect.
-He says he met the girls the day before and gave them his calling card for the tour, even says where they were sitting and what they were doing.
-Later he says he never met the girls and was supposed to the following day.
-The day he claims he was supposed to meet them he shows up at their residence. Who does that?
-He finds their foot behind a tree. The same girls he was supposed to meet, he finds their feet?
-Why was he so concerned when they didn't show up as he claimed? Maybe they had a hangover or slept-in. Did he not think of that?
-Why was he making it so obvious that he was trying to help, by literally going to their house and going inside? 

The other people who should be questioned is the people who run the School the girls were supposed to work at. They were turned away rudely before going on the hike. They mention it in their diary and they say both them and the people they were staying with found it "strange". These girls who wrote in their diaries everyday including the days before the hike, would have probably left a message if they were trying to dial Emergency numbers for a full week. 
I don't think it's a coincidence that the same Tour Guide who claimed he was supposed to meet the 2 girls, shows up at their residence, and then later finds their foot behind a tree. Those are only a few reasons he is suspicious. There is actually a lot more that I won't even get into. Including his 5-Star Trip Advisor reviews that date back to 2013 and they all sound like they were written by him or 1 person. They even hint at what may have happened saying he likes to lead tourists to places where "there aren't many tourists around" and down "hidden trails" and introducing them to indigenous people. He also says he knows a bit of German and Dutch :) with the smiley face, shortly after Dutch girls go missing.

text: I dont like getting into this story particularly because of the misinformation that has been spread as fact. Like how the dog accompanied them up to the trail and came back without them. This is a fabricated story that was told by an elderly guide who son has been in connection of the disappearances of the girls. An easy way to start a story on how they first knew that the girls were missing. Theres a lot more information to this entire story but you REALLLLY have to look for it in the right places. This story took up an entire month of my free time to only realize none of it mattered because its not like i could make a difference about it anyways. These two poor girls were set up from the very beginning the moment they set up plans with that school. I just wish they felt something was wrong when they arrived and were told they were there a week early. Huuuuuuuuge red flag from the very beginning. This problem made the girls venture out into the open and of course, the people who took them; they knew about that very fact. Most of those photos, if not every one; is photoshopped to a degree. With an entire img# wiped off leaving only the # in its place, showing someone had tampered with it through a computer. This is one of the only bizarre cases out there that I have dug into as deep as i possibly could. To the point i was letting it effect the way I imagined everyone around me. Its all sad, everything that happened. Nothing gained, only holes where peoples hearts used to be. R.I.P. Lisanne and Kris.

text: Two elements rule out the theory of a simple accident: the backpack, in perfect condition two months later, and the absence of the bodies. Moreover, there are too many disturbing clues to suggest the involvement of a third party or parties, such as the precise time at which the distress calls were made and the error in the pin codes, since both girls knew their respective codes. In my opinion, this is a clever concealment of evidence in the light of previous disappearances in the area.

text:
They didn't wander off and die alone. There were other people involved. This person (or people) were the ones who took the April 8th photos. They were also responsible for the missing "deleted" photo and the invalid PIN attempts on the iPhone. Let's think about this logically...

Why would a full week elapse between the daytime and nighttime photos? Do you really believe that they wouldn't have tried to use the camera at all over such a long period of time had they been alive and by themselves? As others have mentioned, if they had no supplies, food or fresh water, it's likely that they would have already been dead when those pictures were taken anyways.

Also, I'm pretty sure that given their situation, Kris would have told Lisanne her PIN number at some point between April 1st and April 5th. If Kris was no longer responsive (or dead) by April 6th, Lisanne should have known the PIN number and therefore wouldn't have had that many failed attempts on the security screen. It was obviously someone else trying to get into the device.

text:
Wait, that photo at 4:30, that's gotta be pointing upward to the sky, right? See the shape the leave of the right side shrubs take. That with what seems to be grass on the nearest edge that go out from the camera's view seems to heavily suggest this. The dark spot on the right side of the rock face is also too spread out to suggest that it's a puddle and is more likely a trickle of water which may have been clean enough to drink for natives who could worry less about local disease from the soil. There's also a tiny sapling of sorts growing on the rock face on the left about halfway up the frame with 6 distinguishable leaves growing at a 45 degree angle and the side of the leaf we can see is notably dull meaning that its growing out and facing away from the camera's view. That sort of suggests that the vegetation is so dense around this potential cliff side that the sapling prefers growing its leaves to face upward as if it isn't getting quite enough sun from the area across from the cliff face. It would likely face its leaves in the direction of its current growth if it received unimpeded sunlight from over there. It's such a silty cliff face. I wonder if it receives a lot of rain and the runoff carries a lot of soil with it which gets caught on the side.

I wonder, in an early photo, there's stones and exposed roots along what seems to be a stream, maybe that trickle off the cliff face was the start of that river. It's a thing in survival tips that if you're totally lost and you've found a stream, its worth a shot to follow the stream as towns are usually founded on the sides of water sources. The thing is that you're supposed to follow them downstream, not up, and they may have misremembered and went up or they thought it didn't matter which way.

text:
We may not be able to hear what happened from their own mouths, but there is more than enough evidence to deduce exactly what befell these young women.

They had a week to burn and we're excited to see the country they were visiting. They took a hike with the hosts dog. They decided to go off track, likely to get those cliffside photos like they had been taking. One or both of them slipped and fell. It takes a tremendous force to snap a pelvis in half. Kris has a broken pelvis. The other young girl stayed with her friend. The photos snapped in the dark were likely out of paranoia to frighten away an animal, as they were in pitch black and afraid. They didn't snap the pictures to see because it would've just blinded them with brightness. After around day 5, Kris died from her injuries. The other girl tried relentlessly to unlock the phone but couldn't figure out the code. She was likely very dehydrated and unable to seek help on foot, assuming she wasn't also injured. They both eventually succumb. I can't imagine what it must've been like to be the family and know that if someone just would've found them sooner, they may have survived.

author: @nitech-4208

text: Though murder and rape are very common reasons why young women go missing, especially in this part of the world, getting lost is also a very likely possibility. I feel like there are many holes in the 'murder and kidnapping' theory. People seem to think that the Panamanian police are trying to pass this off as them getting lost when they know there was a violent crime involved for tourism reasons, but there were cases before and after this where someone went missing and the police later found that they had been murdered and raped in one case. Why would the police go thru such trouble and risk to photo-shop photos and make up stories in an age where technology means everyone is watching? Why was there no effort to try to cover up all these other violent crimes? I also think that it is very unlikely any criminal would 'fake' 911 calls every day deep in the jungle as well as take a bunch of random pictures to throw off police. The best and easiest solution in this case would be to destroy the phones and camera along with any other evidence. Also, the calls were made to both 911 and 112, which is the Dutch emergency line. Are you saying this criminal took the time to find out where the girls were originally from, what the emergency line is over there and came up with the idea to call it every day in the case someone goes searching thru their call records? This would have to be some really insightful criminal going thru a ton of trouble to do things the hardest way possible, when as I previously mentioned, destroying the evidence would be the safest and easiest way to not get caught. The bag being found in good condition, in me eyes, probably means it was not in the river at any time and may have been left behind by the girls and found by someone (like a native) who kept it for some time and then returned it/got rid of it once realizing what it was and the implications of having it. You can say it is strange that the bag is in too good of a condition for being in a jungle for so long, but we already know that it was with Lisanne in the jungle for at least a week and if it hasn't showed significant signs of damage in that time then it is not unreasonable to assume it could stay in that condition after a month or more. The bras being in the bag is normal; wearing a bra or underwear while all wet can give you a really bad rash. The girls probably took off their bras and maybe Kris took off her pants too in an effort to get her underwear dry. I also want to address the idea that getting lost on the trail was impossible; that may be sort of true, considering you actually stick to that trail. If the girls had left the trail, even to relieve themselves, there is the possibility they got turned around and could not find their way back to it. If you look at the surrounding area in the final daytime photos taken I'm sure you can imagine how hard it would be to find the path again once you are no longer near the stream and have walked down into the dense foliage. I think that at some point between the time that last photo was taken and before the first call to emergency lines the girls wandered off the trail and got lost. Maybe they were calling because it was going to get dark soon and they could not find their way back or maybe an accident had already occurred. We do know Lisanne's foot was broken as if something had fallen on it when her remains were found and that Kris's head was bleeding at the time the night pictures were taken. It is really too bad they did not leave us any videos explaining what happened or to remember them by, but that isn't evidence that they were attacked and didn't have time to do it. I know that I personally would not want to leave behind any messages; I know my family knows I love them and I would feel pretty ashamed about explaining to them how I had made a mistake and gotten lost. I wouldn't want people viewing those kinds of videos of me after I was dead and I wouldn't want them to be the last way people I loved saw me; after reading her diary, I feel Lisanne was the same way. It is also possible she was sick and had a fever at the time when it finally became apparent that this was the end. I know the parents say that the girls wouldn't ever wander off the trail because they were responsible, but as much as I hate to say it, the fact that they went there alone without a guide even though they had already booked him for the next day was highly impulsive and irresponsible. The clothes they wore and the items they packed also showed that they had no idea what was in store for them in the jungle and once it got dark, cold and wet it is possible they could have suffered hypothermia unless they found some kind of shelter. I'll finish off by saying that the apparent 'bones' and 'shadowy figures' people keep finding in the pictures are obviously your mind playing tricks on you. In the last few photos Kris does look concerned but they are still clearly on the trail though the last one where she is standing in a large junglescape looks like they may have already gotten turned around. I personally would have taken more photos of landmarks but keep in mind the jungle probably all looked the same to them and one of them was probably injured so rationally assessing the situation and retracing their steps became more and more difficult.

text: I feel very sorry for the girls and family. The evidence speaks for itself. It was a cruel crime. The tour guide Feliciano knows about the fate of the two girls. And that video of him showing Kris' parents the way, machete in hand, makes me sick. You can also see that the mood changes in the last two photos of Kris, the perpetrators can probably be seen in photo 509, which is why the tour guide was also in the rooms and the cell phone cables to delete it. And then exactly this guide finds Lisanne's shoe with foot at exactly the right time, in a dense jungle several square kilometers in size, behind a tree in exactly the right place. All the fake reviews on Trip Advisor, NONE mentions the two girls, but emphasizes how great and honest Feliciano is? The backpack, neatly packed with its contents, is found by accident near one of Feliciano's farms, again at exactly the right time? With the money and cell phones to distract from a crime precisely because of that? Guys, I beg of you, does it get any more obvious? If the investigation had been done CORRECTLY, on the first day after the disappearance, the remains of the girls would have been discovered, as hard as it sounds, on one of Feliciano's farms and plantations. But they didn't want to risk it, tourism in this area is one of the main sources of income.

I think the girls were then taken somewhere, murdered and their bodies and belongings were taken back to the jungle to make it look like they were lost in the jungle and died due to an accident, dehydration or starvation....This theory would go hand in hand with why the packsack was completely dry and all articles were completely undamaged when it was found in the middle of the jungle. It would also go hand in hand with the strange disappearance of the one cellphone picture which was said to have been removed by a computer.   
     It just doesn't make sense to me that the girls became lost on the Pianista trail since it was hard to get lost on this well marked trail....unless of course, they were followed by "something or someone" that made them have to take an alternate route.  
     In any case, I do believe that there was a third party involved. Nothing else makes sense.

text: "A forensic anthropologist with Panama’s Institute of Legal Medicine and Forensic Science (IMELCF), a high-ranking examiner, told Jeremy Kryt: “The lesson, unfortunately, is that women still can’t walk safely alone in the campo in Latin America.” He agrees to be interviewed only under the condition of anonymity, saying he has received death threats after discussing sensitive investigations in the past. “That [Bocas] area is swarming with sicarios,” the  IMELCF source says, referring to the cartel smuggling routes that link Panama’s porous eastern coastline with Colombia and Venezuela to the south, and Mexico to the north. “There ought to be a national red alert for foreigners, and especially women,” he says. “But of course that would be bad for tourism.” “Panama is a commercial port for the Sinaloa cartel and others,” he says, and goes on to mention both forced prostitution and organ trafficking as other threats posed by organized crime operating on the isthmus. Part of the problem is that publicizing such dangers could weaken the crucial influx of tourist money, which makes up almost 20 percent of Panama’s GDP. But the problem goes beyond a lack of will, the forensic scientist says. It’s also a lack of skill. “Without competent [law enforcement] officials,” he asks rhetorically, “how can you hope to control crime?”  -  There have been many dozens unsolved murders and disappearances in this remote, rural stretch of Panama since 2009—with more than two thirds of those i the years around 2014. In the majority of these cases, no bodies have been recovered, no rigorous investigations launched by authorities.

text:
Im a avid hiker that has gotten lost in jungle before, this is my theory frm watching the video above,

1) the girls decided to explore more after the smiley photos following the river trail
2) they do not look like they hv much or any real hiking experince and tought if anything, they can just back track their way
3) further photos show more seriousness, bcos they know they r lost but still optimistic
4) they tried calling but not to parents bcos they either do not know how to dial international area code or they ran out of credit, thats why the only numbers they were calling were emergency numbers, n theres no data coverage at this point 
5) photos deleted bcos girls always delete photos they do not like or want ppl to see
6) lost in jungle is no joke even wt day light, imagine night when animals roam more at night
7) the 1am-4am nonstop taking of photo probaly is bcos the girls are scared and theres a predator animal tracking them
8) by this time, or before, one of the girl might already be unconcious or dead, and the other girl coudnt remeber the password n was attempting to switch on and off the phone to try to call the emergency line, they do not know password is not nessacry for emergency calls
9) with thick forest, it is almost impossible to get a line and if they do, the reception would cut off unless the girls know how to climb up the tress
10) the phone is also turn on and off in entire ordeal bcos they wanted to conserve battery
11) by this time, one of the girl is already dead, the other decides to carry on, on her own
12) nothing much is of use frm bag hence it wasnt touched
13) the folded bras were only meant to b use if they find the waterfall n went for a swim n later change to new bras, most of the time, ppl dont change panties n wear on till dry after swim, only upper body garments or cloths
14) by this time, regardless if its the girl left behind or the one continue tracking, a predator would already hv been tracking them / her
15) i can not say why the leg was severe off cleanly, however im guesing, if the bones are scattered everywhere it might be eaten by several predators, if intake at one location, possibly eaten by smaller animals.
16) the bag is dry mayb bcos 
a) it was carried a short distance in the river to a dry rock n left for sometime till it dry
b) a animal carried it some distance n jus threw it there like how monkey do sometimes
c) other reasons of circumstances that has sinister bearing. 
17) the above is jus my personal assumption and nothing more. When i was young, i do not comprehend the severity of getting lost in the jungle, and i also though "its jus 100 meters in front, how can i get lost?" and guys, amateur hikers when panic kicks in is surreal, its like the fear creeps in bcos every tree and river looks like the path u jus pass through. Also, mysterious stories of ppl lost in jungle is almost always add on by many theories, mostly i tink its fictional. Lets keep it simple unless real evidence shown.

Basicaly, naive, lost, panic, inexperience, predator, left too soon, god bless 🙏

My condolences to the friends and family of the deceased.

text:
I have a promising theory that I have not seen anyone esle pick up on. Watch a documentary called "Lost in the Wild a hike into hell". It's about this case. In that documentary two investigators went to the trail the girls were hiking on, they went on foot. Later they went via helicopter deeper into the jungle until they reached the village where the women who found the girls bagpack lives, which ultimately lead to searches in the area the women said she had found the bagpack which lead to the discovery of the girl's remains.

In the documentary, as soon as the two investigators touched down in the village, the village people came out immediately and gathered together quite hostilely, blocking the investigators from the women who found the bag. They said this was because the reward that was put up for the girls was never given to the people who found the bag and therefore they don't trust outsiders. They carried on talking about this reward, it was the first thing they mentioned. What normal person would be worried about a reward in a tragic case like this. And even if a normal person would, would it be the first thing out of your mouth to people wanting to question you about two young women's deaths? Hmmmm 🤔
This is what I think happened. There was money in the girl's bag yet it was not taken. Not by the people who found the bag. Why not?

I think that either the person who had the bag (as I don't believe they just found it) had something to do with the girls murder. Maybe even people in that very village. Or at least they know who did it. I think that if a reward wasn't put up the bag wouldn't have been "found". I think that the killer had the bag and learned of this reward. I then think they got this women to hand it in to police and told her to say that she found this bag down by the river. I think the killer or killers did this knowing that they had placed the girl's bodies nearby and they would be found in the ensuing searches. They said they found the bag in this particular area because they knew that  the girls bodies would be found and they could then collect the reward. I think the women was just told to say she found it in that area so the reward could be collected. Someone in that village or multiple people in that village know who killed those girls.

I even had a brief thought that maybe so many people have gone missing in that area so people can collect the varias rewards put up for people by giving a little info. However this seems too far fetched as rewards aren't always put up and many things could go wrong with that. 

I just think that in this case the killer or killers saw a chance to grab that reward so decided to get someone (someone seemingly harmless and innocent as well) to say she found the bag pack in that area knowing it would lead to the girls remains (because that's where they had put them) and that would hopefully get them the reward. Maybe those remains were placed in that spot on purpose. Who knows..

text: The jungle may seem like an ideal place to get lost since there is fruit and water. But it can be extremely harsh, it's very dense in a way similar to deep snow traversing just a few kilometers can take longer than expected, specially considering the humidity and heat. There are the "invisible" killers, such as yellow fever, malaria, dengue, and other diseases posiblly some that aren't even known/diacovered. Any one of these need pretty serious medical treatment imedietly and start becoming fatal if untreated, yellow fever does not take long to kill you and after a day or so will sevearly affect normal functions same with dengue that will besically leave you unable to move. Not to mention the swarm of poisonous animals such as the Golden tree frog which is indigenous to that region and may look cute but dam they can kill among a plethora of snakes and spiders, and possibly animals we don't know yet. Growing up in Panama I can tell you the rainforest are very unforgiving and extremely diverse, it would not be uncommon to see biologists pull up close to a road and discover a few new species in a square meter, I can only imagine the biodiversity in the middle of the forest. Their plus side is that they where in boquete rather than Darien which is the other side of Panama nutorious for a patch of unexplored rainforest home to ex melitia /farc members that do kidnapping, murdering, drug running as well as human trafficking.  Over the past 50 years 250,000 peaple have died /been abducted in this region that spans part of Panama and Colombia. So the odds that they where killed /disappeared by someone is pretty small, it's the terrain that can be very dangerous.

author: @TriniGamerGirl7

text:
I'm sceptical of the murder theories, although they're understandable, given past crimes involving young women hikers in foreign countries. I have myself been seriously lost in the woods twice, and once guided out a young woman lost in the woods at night while I was camping just off the Appalachian trail. Each time it was dramatic how fast disorientation and panic set in - it's the panic-fear that makes one automatically do the opposite of what one should do. It's not like your car's GPS stops working on a road trip. It's more like falling off a cruise ship and watching it disappear over the horizon. I can only infer that in the most serious cases, especially after days of food deprivation and chronic anxiety and stress, disorientation could become so severe that the two inexperienced girls in the Panama case would begin acting almost pathologically confused, while desperate hope may have led them to forego goodbye messages for the sake of attempts to reach local rescue until the batteries in their phones went dead and it was too late.

I've watched a couple of the better pieced-together videos and I found myself getting sceptical of the murder theories when I saw too much bias in that direction. For example, some of the "happy" photos early on in their hike were slightly distorted or the clouds seemed mis-timed from one snap to the next or the one girl was supposedly a little depressed or anxious looking, and to me all that seemed overly subjective and irrelevant to any criminal activity. The idea of any killers allowing their victims to keep taking photos is ridiculous, not just because it creates possible evidence but because abduction and murder (rape also) is about having complete power and control over someone.

Why would a killer and not the girls turn the phones on and off? Only the girls had any reason to do that repeatedly, and if they had the chance to do so around an abductor, they also would have had the chance to escape. The backpack could have been misplaced by the girls in their disoriented state until a villager found and took it, then returned it, dry, to the same (or a different) spot once they got wind of rescue efforts for the owner of the backpack and realized it might implicate them in more than just “finders, keepers.”

As for the photos in the camera, how would taking dozens of photos of the sky at night serve to mislead police? And the height-distorted photo of Lisanne? Digital photos occasionally are goofy like that (I have a rear-view pic of my motorcycle where the panniers look like two different sizes). The clouds at the trail overlook completely mismatching in photos taken seconds apart? Weird, but how does that suggest foul play, when the girls are posing normally? The deleted photo? A tech-savvy killer would only take the batteries out of the phones and throw everything in the river or bury it all, making deleting photos unnecessary and also increasing the mystery to the killer’s advantage. Anyways, why disguise a murder as an accident, when both possibilities (murder or losing their way) are going to be speculated about regardless? I can certainly see the girls using the camera flashes to attempt signalling toward airplane sounds and checking for hazards in their path (note the one photo of a dangerous drop down a rock). Furthermore, why would a killer force-march two victims miles through a jungle, only to kill them in the middle of nowhere? That makes no sense - killers aren't lazy, but what advantage would there be to the killer?. 

I think these girls just got hopelessly lost, and that leads me back to my own experiences of being lost in the woods - the more you try to guess your way out in a panicked and confused state of mind, the more lost you get. To me, the most important thing about this tragedy isn't how the girls died, but the decisions they made leading up to their disappearance. They'd worked hard as waitresses in the Netherlands to save for the trip and they were young, idealistic and eager, so it's understandable they'd be adventurous. But they'd already reached their goal of living in that small tropical town in Panama and they hadn't even seriously explored the town itself yet. They had a guided hike scheduled for the next day. What was the hurry to get into the jungle? Going to extremes is always a dangerous thing, and getting too adventurous too soon was going to an extreme. I think the girls were their own killers.

text:
It seems like most of the popular comments suspect murder, but to me this seems like a pretty clear case of two girls getting lost. I also just listened to an Unsolved Mysteries podcast about this topic and there is nothing tangible to suspect anyone of foul play. 

One of the "suspicious" points is the deleted photo. For sake of argument, let's say that photo was incriminating for the murderer. Two questions arise: 1) how/why did someone take ~90 photos 7 days later? 2) Why wouldn't the killer have just destroyed the camera? This was a camera, not a camera phone so there wouldn't be any cloud storage so destroying it would leave no trace of what happened. 

The other "suspicious" point is the failed phone login attempts on the 7th - 10th. My theory for this is Lisanne was trying to get into Kris' phone because Lisanne's phone was dead (last used on the 5th) and Kris was either dead or unconscious.


Here is my theory for what happened:
Day 1: Hiking as planned. Possibly they deleted a photo immediately after taking it because it was blurry or something. At some point, one of the girls, probably Kris, gets hurt and they can't find the trail again. If they fell down a cliff, they wouldn't be able to get back up easily and would have lost track of the dog. Even experienced adventurers tend to act irrationally after getting lost. 
Days 2-6: Continue to wander lost in the jungle. The rains started during this time so they were able to drink from streams to keep themselves alive, but likely got sick from parasites in the water. 
Day 7: Kris dies from a fall off of the bridge. Lisanne frantically tries to guess Kris' pin but is unsuccessful.
Day 8: With no phone access, Lisanne uses camera flashes to try to light the way. This could have also been when a photo was deleted immediately after it was taken.
Days 9-11: Lisanne tries to find her way back alone while occasionally trying to guess Kris' pin but eventually succumbs to exhaustion, starvation, or dehydration.
Next 2 months: The girls' remains are scattered around by animals and flowing water.

text:
The amount of fellow Panamanians spewing conspiracy theories is a national embarrassment. (And who apparently failed civics class because they don't know how SINAPROC works.)

While I personally favour the accident hypothesis (being familiar with the area), I am willing to entertain any alternative hypothesis, as it is important to constantly re-evaluate one's beliefs. In particular, some disappearances of Panamanians in subsequent years in the same area are extra sus.

But...

Cannibalistic indigenous peoples? Not only is that super racist, it's also inaccurate. Cannibalism hasn't been part of life in the Isthmus for over a thousand years. The Spanish didn't record any instances of it, in fact.

Organ trafficking? Ludicrous. Ours is a small population, we'd notice the disappearances piling up. Colombia, on the other hand, is more likely: (1) they have over 40 million people (2) violence keeps displaying people, so it's easy to disappear in certain areas (3) moneyed Latin Americans go there for organ transplants.

Sex trafficking? It beggars belief that they'd attempt to traffick young tourists who attract a lot of attention when, thanks to our income inequality, there's a ready supply of beautiful impoverished young women who might jump at the chance for a better life.

If there was foul play, it was regular old murder (whatever the reason) or a rape attempt that went wrong.

text:
The sensationalism in the comments annoys me. There has been a team of literally the best investigators of the country (I'm Dutch) who travelled to Panama after their bodies were finally found, and they all unanimously concluded that they had an accident and lost their way after that. Yet I see this mentioned nowhere in the countless Youtube videos that analyze this case. 

It is thought Kris and Lisanne accidentally fell down a cliff and Kris broke her legs, and they subsequently got lost and disoriented while desperately trying to call for help through their phones. Kris died first which explains the inability to access her phone by Lisanne. And the pictures were most likely a way to scare off wild animals or to signal helicopters who were looking for them their location. 

It's a very sad case, but it was 100% an accident. Literally nobody here in The Netherlands believes there was foul play involved and the case is actually kinda forgotten from public memory because of this. Yet once in a while some dumb Youtube video comes up claiming all these fake and made up stories about serial killers being active there, or their guides stalking them in their rooms or bla bla. All nonsense. It's one thing that annoys me the most about the so-called "true crime community": always with the most straight up weird and made up scenario's and thw "I am 100% sure that this or that morbid thing happened" while there is actually zero evidence for that. Then when there is a thorough police investigation on the matter it gets completely ignored. Stupid.

Also another thing: the police not caring was 100% untrue. Within two days the Dutch police send a group of investigators including sniffer dogs. So many myths and fake news surrounding this case it annoys me to death. Makes me wonder how many other cases I have seen on Youtube that are just straight up bullshit without any way of finding out.

text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 3: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.
